Literature Review: Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) have emerged as a promising technology for treating sensorimotor neurological disorders by creating artificial pathways between the brain and external devices. These interfaces aim to restore motor function, sensory perception, or both, in individuals with impairments due to injury or disease. A critical aspect of BMI development and implementation is the brain's ability to adapt and learn to use these artificial pathways effectively. This review focuses on the role of neural plasticity in sensorimotor BMIs and how it influences their design and performance. Neural plasticity, the brain's ability to reorganize and form new neural connections, plays a crucial role in the successful integration of BMIs with the nervous system. As Carmena et al. (2003) demonstrated in their seminal work, the brain can adapt to control external devices through BMIs, showing significant changes in neural activity patterns over time. This plasticity allows users to improve their control of BMI-operated devices with practice, highlighting the importance of learning in BMI performance. The process of learning to use a BMI involves the formation of new sensorimotor mappings between neural activity and the desired output. Ganguly and Carmena (2009) showed that these mappings can become stable over time, leading to long-term improvements in BMI control. This stability suggests that the brain forms dedicated neural circuits for BMI control, which can be maintained even when not in use for extended periods. In motor BMIs, which aim to restore movement control, neural plasticity enables users to adapt to different decoding algorithms and control strategies. Orsborn et al. (2014) demonstrated that co-adaptive learning, where both the user and the BMI decoder adapt simultaneously, can lead to improved performance and faster skill acquisition. This approach leverages the brain's plasticity to optimize the interface between neural activity and the external device. Sensory BMIs, on the other hand, focus on restoring or augmenting sensory perception. These interfaces rely on the brain's ability to interpret artificial sensory inputs and integrate them into existing neural circuits. Dadarlat et al. (2015) showed that monkeys could learn to use artificial tactile feedback delivered through intracortical microstimulation to guide their behavior, demonstrating the potential for sensory BMIs to provide meaningful information to users. The integration of sensory feedback with motor control is a critical aspect of natural sensorimotor function, and this principle extends to BMIs. Suminski et al. (2010) found that providing congruent visual and proprioceptive feedback during BMI control led to improved performance compared to visual feedback alone. This finding highlights the importance of multimodal sensory integration in BMI design and suggests that incorporating multiple sensory modalities may enhance learning and control. Bidirectional BMIs, which combine both motor control and sensory feedback, present unique challenges and opportunities for leveraging neural plasticity. Bensmaia and Miller (2014) reviewed the potential of bidirectional BMIs to restore both movement and sensation, emphasizing the need for careful consideration of how artificial sensory inputs interact with motor control signals. The close integration of sensory and motor functions in the brain suggests that bidirectional BMIs may be particularly effective in promoting neural plasticity and functional recovery. The design of BMIs can significantly influence the extent and nature of neural plasticity observed during their use. Factors such as the number and location of recording electrodes, the complexity of the control task, and the type of feedback provided can all impact how the brain adapts to the interface. Gulati et al. (2014) demonstrated that the initial performance of a BMI could predict the extent of subsequent learning, suggesting that careful optimization of BMI parameters may enhance the potential for neural plasticity and skill acquisition. Long-term use of BMIs has been shown to induce significant changes in neural circuitry. Koralek et al. (2012) found that rats using a BMI to control an auditory cursor exhibited strengthened connections between motor and auditory areas of the brain. This finding suggests that BMI use can lead to the formation of new functional neural circuits that support the learned sensorimotor mappings. As BMI technology continues to advance, understanding and harnessing neural plasticity will be crucial for developing more effective and adaptable interfaces. Future research should focus on optimizing BMI design to promote beneficial plasticity while minimizing potential negative effects, such as the loss of natural motor skills. Additionally, investigating the long-term effects of BMI use on brain structure and function will be essential for ensuring the safety and efficacy of these devices in clinical applications. In conclusion, neural plasticity plays a fundamental role in the successful implementation of sensorimotor BMIs. By leveraging the brain's ability to adapt and learn, researchers can develop more effective interfaces that provide meaningful improvements in motor control and sensory perception for individuals with neurological disorders. As the field continues to evolve, a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying neural plasticity in BMI use will be crucial for realizing the full potential of this promising technology.
